questions.text:
A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of blisters and redness on his neck and chest for 2 days. He has also had a fever. He is lethargic and has not eaten well since the rash appeared. He has not had coughing, wheezing, or dysuria. He is an only child, and there is no family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows flaccid blisters over his neck and trunk that rupture easily. Areas of erythematous moist skin are also noted. Applying gentle lateral pressure with a finger placed on the skin of the trunk results in a blister. Oropharyngeal examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12 g/dL


Leukocyte count
22,000/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
77%


Eosinophils
3%


Lymphocytes
18%


Monocytes
2%


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
60 mm/h


Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is a blistering skin disorder that typically results from toxemia following Staphylococcus aureus infections. The initial focal infection is not always apparent. SSSS most often affects children less than 6 years of age due to impaired renal clearance of the exfoliative toxins and a lack of circulating antitoxins. This condition typically manifests with flaccid, easily ruptured bullae, a positive Nikolsky sign, and widespread desquamation of the skin with moist red underlying tissue (scalded appearance). Unlike Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis, SSSS spares mucosal membranes. Patients with SSSS often have findings of systemic illness (fever, lethargy) and may present with signs of hypovolemia.
Image Description:

Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcal impetigo (nonbullous impetigo) most commonly affects the face and extremities and manifests with pustular and vesicular lesions on an erythematous base that rupture and form honey-colored crusts. Positive Nikolsky sign is not a feature of nonbullous impetigo, and systemic signs (e.g., fever, lethargy) are uncommon.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

C) INCORRECT:

Although pemphigus vulgaris can manifest with a positive Nikolsky sign and flaccid blisters over the face and trunk, mucosal involvement is almost always present and often precedes cutaneous manifestations. Additionally, the peak incidence of pemphigus vulgaris is between 40 and 60 years, and children are rarely affected.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

D) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid typically manifests with tense rather than flaccid blisters. Additionally, blisters in bullous pemphigoid are intensely pruritic, and positive Nikolsky sign is not a feature. Furthermore, this condition most commonly affects older adults.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

E) INCORRECT:

Although toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) can manifest with high fever, blisters over the face and trunk, a positive Nikolsky sign, and signs of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension), the oropharyngeal mucosa is typically affected. Moreover, TEN is most commonly associated with a history of medication use.
Image Description:

Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

F) INCORRECT:

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) manifests in young children with blistering induced by trauma or friction. Signs of systemic illness (e.g., fever, leukocytosis) are usually not present unless there is a secondary infection. Additionally, EBS is a genetic disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance, and a positive family history is typically present.
Image Description:

Right foot, ankle, and lower leg of an infant.

There are three large ruptured blisters over the big toe and posterior aspect of the ankle and medial malleolus. There are also two, unruptured blisters (approx. 1–2 cm) on the medial aspect of the lower leg and another in the popliteal fossa.

These findings are typical of epidermolysis bullosa.
questions.hint: The formation of a blister upon lateral pressure on the skin is a positive Nikolsky sign.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, irritability, and rash for 3 days. The rash started around the mouth before spreading to the trunk and extremities. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with flaccid bullae on the neck, flexural creases, and buttocks. Gentle pressure across the trunk with a gloved finger creates a blister. Oropharyngeal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytotoxic T-cell release of granulysin with resulting damage to the keratinocytes is the pathophysiologic mechanism of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (or toxic epidermal necrolysis). Patients also present with fever, a blistering rash, and a positive Nikolsky sign. However, mucosal involvement is almost always present. Furthermore, SJS is usually caused by a delayed immune-mediated reaction to drugs. Since there is no mention of a newly initiated medication, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

B) CORRECT:

Cleavage of desmoglein-1 by exfoliative toxin is the mechanism underlying SSSS, a blistering skin disorder that results from toxemia following focal Staphylococcus aureus infections (usually of the nasopharynx). Desmoglein-1 is a desmosomal protein located in the granular layer of the epidermis and responsible for attaching the keratinocytes to one another. Loss of the cell-to-cell attachments results in intraepidermal fissure formation, which presents as fragile, flaccid blisters. Bullous impetigo is also caused by staphylococcal exfoliative toxins but remains localized, in contrast to SSSS.

Treatment of SSSS consists of IV antibiotics and supportive care. Although most patients respond well to conventional therapy, SSSS is a potentially fatal condition with an increased mortality rate in adults.
Image Description:

There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

C) INCORRECT:

Strains of group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) that produce erythrogenic exotoxin A are the causative agent of scarlet fever, which presents with an erythematous, sandpaper-like rash. It is not a blistering disorder and resolution of the exanthem takes place by desquamation instead of vesicle/bullae formation. Moreover, patients with scarlet fever usually have flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, palatal petechiae, and a white-coated or strawberry-red tongue. This patient's normal oropharyngeal examination makes this diagnosis very unlikely.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.

D) INCORRECT:

In children, bacterial invasion of the skin is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus infection and manifests as impetigo. A clinical presentation similar to this patients can be seen in the less common bullous variant of impetigo, which is caused by staphylococcal extoxins that destroy keratinocyte adhesions. Patients also present with flaccid, intraepidermal bullae on the trunk and upper extremities. However, the blisters are localized, not diffuse, and on a nonerythematous base, and are associated with a negative Nikolsky sign.

Although it is not the most likely mechanism of this child's skin disorder, impetigo can trigger it in rare cases.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins in the stratum spinosum are a diagnostic finding in pemphigus vulgaris. Damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation, a positive Nikolsky sign, and flaccid blisters over the face and trunk. However, affected patients are usually > 30 years of age and mucosal involvement is very common (often precedes cutaneous manifestations).
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

F) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies directed against hemidesmosomal proteins of the epithelial basement membrane can be found in bullous pemphigoid. Although the absence of mucosal lesions supports this diagnosis, bullous pemphigoid is more common in elderly patients and the blisters are usually large and tense, not flaccid. Also, Nikolsky sign would be negative (unlike in this patient), as the lesions are located subepidermally.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.
questions.hint: This infant's fever, blistering rash, and positive Nikolsky sign without mucosal involvement are indicative of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a 1-day history of fever and widespread skin erythema that began on the face. Examination findings are shown. The child is irritable and has positive Nikolsky sign with flaccid blisters. Mucous membranes are unaffected. Vital signs are T, 38.9°C (102.0°F); P, 130; BP, 85/50 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are contraindicated in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, as this is an infectious condition requiring antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, steroids can worsen the underlying staphylococcal infection.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of fever, positive Nikolsky sign, flaccid blisters, and spared mucous membranes in a young child indicates staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. IV nafcillin and inpatient supportive care, including IV fluids for hemodynamic support, are required.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are insufficient for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which requires intravenous therapy due to the systemic nature of the toxin-mediated condition. Additionally, this patient needs inpatient monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are contraindicated in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome because the condition is caused by bacterial exotoxins. Steroids suppress the immune response and may worsen the infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Although burn center referral may be warranted for severe cases, another step in management is the priority for treating the underlying infection.
